website_summaries.verdict: One of the best rear mountain biking derailleurs known for extra durability on tough trails while mountain biking.
pros: Heavy-duty construction with an outside carbon fiber cage allows the derailleur to resist dents and scratches
Outer jockey wheel rides smoothly through gear changes without getting hung up on the chain
cons: Heavier and more expensive than other rear bike derailleurs

customer_reviews.title: works as good as those clutch derailleurs without having to pay clutch derailleur price
customer_reviews.text: Using this in place of my Sram Force 1 clutch derailleur. No need for a clutch on the road, even with a 1x setup. This has enough tension to keep the chain tight enough. Maybe if I were riding on cobbles or doing cyclocross, I'd think about a clutch derailleur but I wanted a little less drag on my chain for the road.
customer_reviews.author: Kevin M Bania

customer_reviews.title: It allows for the 11 32T cassette
customer_reviews.text: The benefit of the mid size is that you can run a 32T ring on the back. If your largest cassette ring is 28T or smaller, the short version is best. I have two bikes and have the mid size on both. One cassette has 28T with a compact crank 50/34, and the other has 32T cassette with a 52/36 crank. I can swap back wheels if there is a lot of hill climbing on a ride.
customer_reviews.author: James Mason

customer_reviews.title: Shifts well
customer_reviews.text: Shifts the rear cogs well, and was easy to adjust. The Force derailleur feels slightly stiffer than the the Apex derailleur it replaced, and the shifts feel incrementally crisper than before.

customer_reviews.title: The mid cage WiFli with 11-32 cassette was great but I could never get her tuned in just ...

The short cage with 11-28 cassette runs as smooth as any Shimano Ultegra kit. No longer disappointed with my Sram Force.

customer_reviews.title: Great performance. Best value for money from SRAM.
customer_reviews.text: SRAM Force 22 is a great groupset. Smooth and lightweight. Short cage rear derailleur weighs in at 180g, 2g more than the 178g claimed by SRAM (difference could be due to inaccuracy of my scales). Best value for money in my opinion compared to the rest of SRAM's offerings. For 1/3 the price of SRAM Red's rear derailleur, it's a great deal for what you can get that's closest to Red 22.

product_meta.title: SRAM Force 22 Rear Derailleur
product_meta.description: All the best things, from Tufnel's amp to SRAM's Force 22 groupset, are designed to max out at 11. The Force 22 Rear Derailleur is a key part of the new Force 22 drivetrain, and it gives you smooth, laser-guided 11-speed shifting under even the most demanding conditions. SRAM didn't design the Force 22 from scratch. To ensure precise shifting no matter the gear combination, it took the 1:1 Exact Actuation technology from its award-winning 10-speed Red groupset. This means that you'll pull the same length of cable in every shift, regardless of gear, so shifting stays super precise and adjustment free. More speeds means smaller gaps between gears, too, so each shift is lightning fast. Not content to update the shifting mechanism, SRAM also updated the pulleys and the materials used in the Force 22. The AeroGlide pulley system ensures super-smooth, quiet, and efficient pulley action, and a new elastomer coating reduces noise even further for a more pleasant riding experience. There's a new barrel adjuster, too, which lets you dial in micro-adjustments without the need for tools. As far as materials are concerned, the Force 22 is made from a combination of rugged aluminum, carbon fiber, and magnesium for the ultimate combination of stiffness, lightness, and durability.
feature_bullets: Extended B-Knuckle for improved clearance for 28t cassettes
Exact Actuation shifting provides fast, accurate shifts
Outside Carbon Cage designed for precise chain management and new reduced profile inner cage
